body:
In command_line_scan() for MSWIN, expand `"~\"` or `"~/"` prefixed paths to
the USERPROFILE environment variable for the user's profile directory.

Fix #23901

comment_data.body: does this function not expand `~/` on unix? doesn't seem like the right place to do this then.
That function is `static`, how do I get `homedir` out of `env.c`?
On unix I believe the shell does this itself.
This is the wrong place to put this. It should be in the "EDITOR" subsection of the "NEW FEATURES" section.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,6 +18,12 @@ BREAKING CHANGES IN HEAD                                    *news-breaking-dev*
 The following changes to UNRELEASED features were made during the development
 cycle (Nvim HEAD, the "master" branch).
 
+MAIN
+
+* On Windows, filename arguments on the command-line prefixed with "~/" or
+  "~\" are now expanded to the user's profile directory, not a relative path
+  to a literal "~" directory.
+

comment_data.body: On second thought, it may be better to use `vim_getenv("HOME")` here. That'll return the `homedir` variable in os/env.c (which is consistent with other types of expansions), and doesn't require checking for `NULL`.

Does this happen before `init_homedir`, or why not use `os_homedir` ? $HOME is not always available Windows.

Also needs test coverage.

But I'm confused about why this is needed, because https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23901#issuecomment-2033479836 indicated that powershell would provide this feature without every program needing to implement it manually.

comment_regular_data.body: What *problem* is this solving? Give a specific use-case, describing the steps exactly.

> What _problem_ is this solving? Give a specific use-case, describing the steps exactly.

So, PowerShell on Windows recently removed the feature where arguments such as `~/.ssh/config` or `~/.vimrc` are expanded to `${env:USERPROFILE}/.ssh/config` etc..

What this means is, in PowerShell, when you run a command such as:

```powershell
nvim ~/.ssh/config
```
, what happens is that nvim tries to open `${PWD}/~/.ssh/config` because that looks like a relative path to a literal `~` directory to it.

If you don't want to do this that's up to you, I believe this is a harmless enough change because in these cases the user is very unlikely to want to open a file in literal `~` relative directory. It's a huge annoyance for me in PowerShell because I run these commands frequently and now I have to run a command such as:

```powershell
nvim (gi ~/.ssh/config)
```
, instead to get the file I want.
I don't understand the lint failure, what am I doing wrong there?

> nvim (gi ~/.ssh/config)

`nvim "+n ~/.ssh/config"` is another workaround. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23901#issuecomment-1575551962

We might want to address this, but need to be sure that `fix_fname` is the right place to do it. (I haven't analyzed the codepaths involved.)

> PowerShell on Windows recently removed the feature where arguments such as `~/.ssh/config` or `~/.vimrc` are expanded to `${env:USERPROFILE}/.ssh/config` etc..

I had heard differently in another issue. Maybe it's configurable? Can you provide a reference (which should have been mentioned from the start, in the PR description)

> We might want to address this, but need to be sure that fix_fname is the right place to do it. (I haven't analyzed the codepaths involved.)

So I tried to do this in `os_open()` in `os/fs.c` first, but it is too late to do it there because `fix_fname()` has already converted the path to an absolute path to a relative `~` directory, this is why I put it there.

> I had heard differently in another issue. Maybe it's configurable? Can you provide a reference (which should have been mentioned from the start, in the PR description)

There used to be an experimental feature for this in `get-experimentalfeature` that you could enable, I don't remember which exactly, but it has been removed.

In the unreleased development version of PowerShell, which may not be released for quite a while yet, there is an experimental feature for this, `PSNativeWindowsTildeExpansion`, see [here](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/experimental-feature-windows.json).

I believe it would be better if we address this in neovim, because this PowerShell experimental feature will not be available for a while yet, and when it is it would require enabling it, and if this is done in neovim it would also work in WinPS (`powershell.exe`) and `cmd.exe`.

I should also mention that the PowerShell completion behavior for tilde paths has also recently changed. Before, when you would type:

```powershell
nvim ~/.ssh/config<TAB>
```
, it would expand to the absolute path, but PowerShell no longer expands tilde paths to absolute paths, it expands them to canonical tilde paths, leading to the behavior in neovim that I described.
If there is not already an issue tracking this, please consider opening an issue with your notes.
Done, the [issue](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23901) you linked was it.
@justinmk ping, any planned action on this PR? I do believe I put the code in the right place and including this feature is justified, and I would really like it to be released for Windows users.
CI is failing, you need to run `cmake --build build --target format` to format the code.

> @zeertzjq
>

But I wonder, do we want this expansion for only file arguments or for any file handling in general, e.g. from vimscript, ex commands, etc.. I think the latter behavior would be nicer, because then I can do e.g. `:e ~/.ssh/config` and it would work as well.
>

For Ex commands this is already done in `expand_env_esc()`.
Sorry I should have tested this before posting, that does indeed work. However, `:echo readfile("~/.ssh/config")` does not work, and it does not work in my current implementation either.

@zeertzjq 

And in fact, `:echo readfile("~/.ssh/config")` does not work on UNIX either.

I'd like to propose a solution for full support for tilde expansion on Windows and UNIX for all neovim file operations. I think I know how to do this now.

- Fix `vim_isAbsName()` in `path.c` to return true for paths with a tilde expansion, because they are in fact absolute paths, this way `fix_fname()` in `path.c` will not "fix" them.
- Perform the expansion in `os_open()` in `os/fs.c` using a helper function on both UNIX and Windows.

I want to handle `~username/` expansions as well, this may be of use to admin users. This is much harder to do on Windows and I may not be able to fully support it, but I will try for at least partial support.

If you don't like this idea I will go with your solution of putting the expansion in `main.c` because that does in fact fix the main problem I am trying to fix.

> I'd like to propose a solution for full support for tilde expansion on Windows and UNIX for all neovim file operations.

I don't think this should be supported. Hardly any other tools or libraries support this, and it will cause inconsistencies (with lua or luv) and bugs.
@zeertzjq How's this?
@zeertzjq can you look again please
@zeertzjq done.
@zeertzjq sorry, fixed.

@zeertzjq @justinmk @dundargoc

Really appreciate your help with this, thank you.

Looking forward to this being released so I can tell my PowerShell friends about it.

I am going to try to do another PR here for the format target on Windows.

I am going to try to get this feature into vim as well.

> Does this happen before init_homedir, or why not use os_homedir ? $HOME is not always available Windows.

`$HOME` should always be available on Windows, at least in any normal situation. Neovim would probably not function correctly at all in that case.

If it does happen that it is not available in some situation we can deal with that separately, I think.

This code is in `os/env.c`, `os_homedir()` gets the homedir from libuv, `init_homedir()` sets `homedir` from `os_homedir()` while `vim_getenv("HOME")` returns `homedir`. So this is essentially the same thing.

I should mention that I did test this and it does work as intended.

> Also needs test coverage.

I will do a separate PR for that.

> But I'm confused about why this is needed, because https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23901#issuecomment-2033479836 indicated that powershell would provide this feature without every program needing to implement it manually.

It is currently a major usability issue.

For many PowerShell users, `nvim` is the native program they will most often call with tilde paths.

Someone mentioned that tab completion for tilde paths may be backported to the full expansion behavior, but it is unknown whether and when that will happen. And that would still require tab expansion.

This will also work in WinPS (`powershell.exe`, version 5) which will not be updated for a very long time to come. It does expand tilde paths with tab, but this will work without expansion.

It may also be helpful for people using other shells, I don't know.

The experimental feature for handling tilde path arguments to native programs in the development branch of PowerShell will most likely not be available for months to come, and even then it may only be available as an experimental feature that requires it to be enabled manually.

Given that this is not a large change, and does not break anything, I think it's justified, given that it is a major usability issue for Windows users.

You may consider PowerShell not handling tilde paths itself like a UNIX shell absolutely ridiculous, and I agree, but that is the situation we are in.

> `$HOME` should always be available on Windows, at least in any normal situation.

Since when? https://superuser.com/a/607110 Perhaps you are only referring to powershell.

> Neovim would probably not function correctly at all in that case.

Completey wrong. `os_homedir` existst to deal with the lack of $HOME, at least on older(?) Windows versions or cmd.exe.



This does not inspire me with confidence in this PR.
@justinmk Please read the source code of `vim_getenv()`.
